intro: Corydalis juncea, commonly known as the lesser corydalis, is a flowering plant native to regions of Asia, including China, Korea, and Japan. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes poppies and other flowering plants. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and produces delicate, spurred flowers in shades of pink, purple, or white. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture. Corydalis juncea is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
